Graphical abstract This work discussed the catalytic performance towards CO oxidation over unsupported nanoporous Ag (np-Ag) catalysts synthesized by dealloying of Mg77Ag23 (at.%) alloy under controllable etching conditions. The np-Ag catalysts were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM), energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) analysis, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (UV-vis DRS). The np-Ag catalysts exhibit an open, bicontinuous interpenetrating ligament-channel structure. The np-Ag samples fabricated under different conditions possess distinct feature sizes ranging from ∼15.7 to ∼142.6nm. Without any heat-treatment, the as-obtained np-Ag catalysts were utilized for catalysis tests. The results reveal that the catalytic activity of the unsupported np-Ag catalysts is comparable with or even better than that of supported Ag catalysts with heat-treatment. In addition, the role of residual Mg and feature size in the catalytic activity of the np-Ag catalysts has been clarified. The catalytic mechanism of the present unsupported np-Ag catalysts has also been discussed. Keywords Nanoporous Ag Unsupported catalyst CO oxidation Catalytic activity Dealloying 1 Introduction Carbon monoxide (CO) is a common by-product produced from incomplete combustion reactions, and a highly toxic gas in the urban areas at the same time. Exposure to air containing CO with a concentration greater than 100ppm can exert a detrimental impact on the nervous system and cardiac function of human beings [1–5]. Due to the negative effects, CO processing has received tremendous attention in the past decades. Attempts in completing CO combustion reactions have shown that catalytic oxidation is an efficient way to tackle this urgent environmental concern. Heterogeneous catalysts, such as oxide-supported platinum-group metals, are widely used in minimizing CO emission from automobiles [6,7]. Besides this, coinage metals such as Au and Ag, were historically regarded as the ones with poor activity due to their filled d-bands which result in higher activation barriers than transition metals with partially filled d-bands [8]. However, the work by Haruta et al. [9,10] has indicated that gold nanoparticles supported on 3d transition metal oxides including α-Fe2O3, Co3O4 and NiO show high catalytic activity towards CO oxidation at low temperatures. The high catalytic activity of supported Au catalysts has been attributed to preparation methods, pretreatment conditions, particle size and contact interface between Au and the oxide support [11,12]. Compared to Pt and Au, Ag is a relatively inexpensive metal. Nanosized Ag supported on different oxides shows catalytic activities towards CO oxidation and has been fabricated through various methods [13–16]. Like supported Au, the catalytic behavior of Ag catalysts loaded on oxide supports can be partially attributed to the electronic interaction between support and Ag as well as the contribution from pretreatment processes [16–19]. In the past few years, nanoporous metals have aroused intensive research interests in the fields of catalysis [20], sensors [21], actuators [22] and energy conversion/storage system [23,24], due to their high specific surface areas and peculiar bicontinuous ligament-channel structure. For example, Yin et al. [25] reported that nanoporous Au (np-Au) displays an excellent catalytic behavior towards D-glucose oxidation. Dealloying has been proved to be an effective and facile method to prepare nanoporous metals through selective etching one or more less noble element(s) out of suitable precursors [26,27]. Usually, dealloying happens when the concentration of noble element(s) in precursor alloys is below a threshold value and the electrochemical potential is above the critical one [28,29]. Surface diffusion and reorganization of noble element(s) occur during dealloying, which leads to the unique three-dimensional (3-D) bicontinuous interpenetrating ligament-channel structure [30–32]. Hayes et al. [33] fabricated monolithic nanoporous Cu via dealloying of Mn–Cu solid solution. Wang et al. [34] performed research on tuning the feature size of dealloyed Al–Cu samples through temperature control. It is worth mentioning that the emergence of nanoporous metals has greatly contributed to the development of unsupported metal catalysts for gas oxidation [35]. For example, Xu et al. [36] fabricated np-Au catalyst with ligament size below 6nm by dealloying Ag–Au alloy in concentrated nitric acid, and the np-Au shows an outstanding catalytic behavior towards CO oxidation at low temperatures. Wittstock et al. [37] have reported high turnover frequencies for the catalytic oxidation of methanol over np-Au below 80°C. Meanwhile, controversies over the catalytic mechanism of nanoporous metals have never ceased since the remaining components or their oxides are suspected to interact with noble elements in the dealloyed samples and their roles are not negligible in catalytic behaviors. For example, Haruta [38] made comments on the mechanism of CO catalytic oxidation over np-Au synthesized by dealloying of Ag–Au alloy, and argued that the residual Ag may further enhance the catalytic properties of np-Au. Bäumer and co-workers [39] believe that the dealloyed Ag–Au should be regarded as a bimetallic catalyst for the questionable role of residual Ag in CO catalytic oxidation. Thus it is of great significance to further develop unsupported nanoporous metal catalysts and shed light on the origin of their catalytic activities both in fundamental science as well as engineering applications. Besides the extensive study on np-Au catalysts, to the best of our knowledge, researches on catalytic behaviors of other unsupported nanoporous metals are seldom reported [40]. For example, although nanoporous Ag (np-Ag) can be fabricated by dealloying of Mg–Ag alloy precursors in organic/inorganic acids [41], the information on the CO catalytic oxidation over np-Ag is rarely available. It is reasonable to suppose that np-Ag catalysts own wide space of exploration in CO oxidation, due to their facile synthesis strategy of dealloying, tunable feature size and unique ligament-channel structure. Thus in this work, we aim to investigate CO catalytic oxidation over unsupported np-Ag catalysts synthesized by dealloying. Through clarifying the role of remaining Mg and feature size in the catalytic properties, we also attempt to illustrate the catalytic origin of np-Ag catalysts and optimize the catalytic performance via varying dealloying conditions/parameters such as dealloying duration, electrolyte and temperature. It is well known that most of the intensively studied supported Ag catalysts for CO oxidation typically endure high-temperature treatment in O2 ambience to boost activity [16–19], whereas catalysis tests reveal that the unsupported np-Ag, without the energy-consuming heat-treatment, still shows excellent catalytic activity and stability towards CO oxidation. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Mg77Ag23 (at.%, nominal composition) precursor ingot was firstly prepared from pure Mg (99.9wt.%) and pure Ag (99.9wt.%) in a resistance furnace under protection of covering fluxes. With a single roller melt spinning apparatus, the ingot was remelted in a quartz tube through high-frequency induction heating and rapidly solidified into ribbons (20–50μm in thickness and 2–5mm in width) under an argon atmosphere. To obtain np-Ag samples with different remaining Mg contents, we performed the dealloying of Mg77Ag23 in 1wt.% tartaric acid solution at ambient temperature (20°C) for different durations (30 and 70min). In addition, 1wt.% citric acid and 1wt.% hydrochloric acid solutions were used to obtain np-Ag samples with different feature sizes (70min for citric acid and 10min for hydrochloric acid). The dealloying of the Mg77Ag23 ribbons was also carried out in the 1wt.% tartaric acid at 0°C for 140min using an electro-thermostatic water cabinet. All the as-dealloyed samples were rinsed with ultra-pure water and dehydrated ethanol for several times. 2.2 Catalysis test Catalysis tests were conducted in a fixed-bed reactor for CO oxidation. Quartz sand (0.5g) was used to disperse the np-Ag catalyst (20mg) in a quartz tube. A gas mixture with a volume ratio of CO/O2/N2 =1/10/89 was fed into the reaction chamber at a total flow rate of 40mLmin−1. Temperature control programmer was used to set the initial and final temperatures as well as the heating rate (3°Cmin−1). The outlet gas composition was analyzed by an on-line gas analyzer, and CO conversion was calculated by the following expression: CO conversion=CO2 out/(CO2 out +COout)×100%, where CO2 out and COout were the corresponding concentration of CO2 and CO at the outlet. 2.3 Microstructural characterization The phase constitution of the np-Ag catalysts (before and after catalysis tests) was characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD, Rigaku D/max-rB) with Cu Kα radiation. The field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM, Quanta FEG 250) was employed to study the morphology and nanoporous structure of the np-Ag catalysts before and after catalysis. Energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) analysis was used to determine the chemical compositions of the np-Ag catalysts. Here, area analysis was used for EDX and at least two areas were selected in order to obtain the compositions of the catalysts. Surface elemental information was detected by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, ESCALAB 250) and the valence of Ag was further characterized by UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectra (UV-vis DR spectra). For clarity, we denoted the np-Ag catalysts fabricated under different conditions/parameters as the following samples: (I) np-Ag catalyst by dealloying the Mg–Ag alloy in the 1wt.% tartaric acid solution at 20°C for 30min, (II) extending the dealloying time of 30min in sample I to 70min for sample II, (III) np-Ag catalyst obtained in the 1wt.% citric acid solution at 20°C for 70min, (IV) np-Ag catalyst obtained in the 1wt.% hydrochloric acid solution at 20°C for 10min, and (V) np-Ag catalyst obtained in the 1wt.% tartaric acid solution at 0°C for 140min. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Microstructure of np-Ag Fig. 1a shows the typical macrograph of the as-synthesized np-Ag samples. The np-Ag catalysts (sample I–III and V) exhibit golden metallic luster, despite silvery white appearance of bulk Ag. The XRD results confirm that all the np-Ag catalysts (sample I–V) are composed of a single face centered cubic (f.c.c.) Ag (PDF #65–2871) phase. Fig. 1b shows typical XRD patterns of the np-Ag catalysts for sample I, II and V before and after catalysis/stability tests. There are five diffraction peaks (2θ =38.11, 44.30, 64.44, 77.40 and 81.54°) in the XRD patterns of all the np-Ag samples, corresponding to (111), (200), (220), (311) and (222) planes of f.c.c. Ag, respectively. Specifically, sample I and II have the same phase constitution, demonstrating that the dealloying time of 30min is enough to fully dealloy the Mg77Ag23 precursor in the 1wt.% tartaric acid. In fact, surface diffusion of more noble element(s) has been proved to be the rate-limiting step during dealloying, compared with the dissolution of less noble element(s) [42,43]. Sample V shows the similar XRD pattern with sample II (Fig. 1b), indicating that at low temperature Mg can still be dissolved into the solution although this process is evidently slowed down. It can be noted that there is no change for sample II before and after catalysis test, and the same scenario can also be found for sample V before and after catalysis/stability test at 195°C (Fig. 1b). Inspite of exposure to the gas mixture containing O2 in a relatively wide temperature range, Ag2O or AgO cannot be detected by XRD. Fig. 2a and b shows the micro-morphology and nanoporous structure of the as-prepared np-Ag catalysts (sample I and II). The self-similar 3-D bicontinuous interpenetrating ligament-channel structure can be clearly found for sample I and II, regardless of the different dealloying durations. The feature size of the np-Ag catalysts was evaluated by measuring the sizes of 80 ligaments-channels and averaging them. Sample I has a ligament size of 15.7±2.9nm (Fig. 2a). Even if the dealloying duration was extended to 70min (sample II), the ligament size is only 24.7±5.0nm (Fig. 2b), which is less than the reported feature size of np-Ag synthesized through different preparation methods (ranging from ∼30nm to submicrometer) [44,45]. Based on the surface diffusion controlled coarsening mechanism, the surface diffusivity of Ag adatoms (D s) along the alloy/solution interface can be evaluated by the following equation [46,47]: (1) D s = [ d ( t ) ] 4 k T 32 γ t a 4 where k is the Boltzmann constant (1.3806×10−23 JK−1), T is the dealloying temperature (K), γ is the surface energy of Ag, t is the dealloying duration and a represents lattice constant of Ag (0.4086nm). It should be noted that the surface energy for Ag varies from ∼1.0 to ∼1.3Jm−2 for different lattice planes and we adopted an average value of 1.2Jm−2 in this work [48]. The D s value is 1.3×10−19 m2 s−1 for sample I, which is comparable with the diffusivity of sample II (3.3×10−19 m2 s−1). In addition, we can roughly estimate the specific surface area of our np-Ag samples using the following prediction expression provided by ref. [49], (2) S = C ρ d l d l d c α S, C and ρ in equation (2) represent specific surface area of np-Ag, dimensionless constant depending on pore geometry and bulk solid density of Ag, respectively. d l is the size of ligaments, whereas d c is the size of channels. α is a constant and its accurate value is not given in ref. [49]. For the situation in which d l and d c are comparable, equation (2) can be simplified into equation (3): (3) S = C ρ d l Here, the value of C is 3.7 for random nanoporous materials such as np-Ag in this work [49]. Thus we can obtain the specific surface areas of sample I and II (22.5 and 14.3m2 g−1, respectively). The calculated values of S for sample I and II are larger than the reported specific surface area of np-Ag (3.47m2 g−1 in ref. [50] and ∼6 to ∼11.47m2 g−1 in ref. [45]). The typical EDX spectra of sample I and II are shown in Fig. 2c and d, respectively. It is obvious that Ag is the predominant component in the np-Ag samples, which is in accord with the XRD analysis. Although Mg has been etched out of the precursor on a large scale, there is still difference in the remaining Mg content between sample I and II. The residual Mg content is around 8.3at.% in sample I, whereas only 2.2at.% Mg can be detected in sample II. This suggests that the extension of another 40min still plays an important role in further etching Mg out of the dealloyed sample. The difference in Mg content for these two samples can be an important parameter to analyze the influence of remaining Mg in the np-Ag catalysts on the catalytic activity towards CO oxidation. Fig. 3a–c shows the microstructure of three np-Ag catalysts (sample III, IV and V) with apparently different ligament-channel sizes. For sample III and IV, both the distinct dealloying durations (70min for sample III and 10min for sample IV) and the difference in feature size (76.6±18.8 and 142.6±44.5nm for sample III and IV, respectively) are observed. The results in Fig. 3a and b suggest that, at the same dealloying temperature, solution type can evidently affect the dealloying process [41]. Specifically, in the case of hydrochloric acid treatment, an apparently shortened dealloying time (only 10min) is requisite for sample IV. Comparing with citric acid, hydrochloric acid as a strong acid can ionize more H+ which can dissolve Mg to form Mg2+, leading to the reduced resistance for surface diffusion of Ag and accelerated dealloying process. The ligament size of sample IV is nearly twice of sample III, which is possibly attributed to the influence of Cl− since Cl− adsorption has been revealed to play an important role in coarsening the ligaments of np-Au and np-Pd [51]. Similar reports can also be found in ref. [52,53], in which Cl− exerts a deep influence in enhancing the diffusivity of Au. The value of D s for sample IV (2.6×10−15 m2 s−1) is two orders of magnitude larger than that of sample III (3.1×10−17 m2 s−1). In addition, the calculated specific surface areas for sample III and IV are about 4.6m2 g−1 and 2.5m2 g−1, respectively. As shown in Fig. 3c, the ligament size of sample V (19.7±4.4nm) is comparable with that of sample II, demonstrating that the resistance for surface diffusion of Ag for sample V at 0°C prominently increases since the dealloying duration (140min) is twice of that (70min) for sample II. The corresponding D s value for sample V is around 6.3×10−20 m2 s−1, which is almost one order of magnitude lower than that of sample I and II. The small ligament size of sample V corresponds with a relatively high specific surface area of 17.9m2 g−1. 3.2 Role of residual Mg and ligament size in catalysis Fig. 4a shows the conversion of CO over our as-prepared np-Ag catalysts as a function of the reaction temperature for sample I and II. A sigmoid curve can be seen for sample I. And the ignition temperature T 5% (temperature of 5% CO conversion) is around 65°C for sample I (Fig. 4a). With increasing temperature, the conversion rapidly increases. And the temperature of 50% conversion is around 110°C. 95% conversion of CO is achieved at 145°C, and further rise in reaction temperature witnesses the complete conversion of CO. A curve plateau occurs in the subsequent temperature rise. Similar scenario can also be found for sample II which exhibits close relationship between CO conversion and temperature (Fig. 4a). Namely, the catalytic activity of sample II shows no apparent difference with sample I, in spite of their different residual Mg contents. This suggests that the remaining Mg in the np-Ag catalysts has no obvious influence on their catalytic behaviors because another factor, the ligament size of the two samples, is comparable. Fig. 4b shows the microstructure of sample II after catalysis test. The typical bicontinuous ligament-channel structure can be reserved, but a little coarsening occurs during catalysis test. The feature size of sample II after catalysis test is 34.9±10.0nm, which is slightly larger than that (24.7±5.0nm) before catalysis. Since the catalytic oxidation occurs under a heating condition, intraparticle atomic diffusion will be promoted and leads to the increase in the feature size of np-Ag during reaction. Fig. 5a shows the catalytic behaviors of the np-Ag catalysts (sample III, IV and V) towards CO oxidation. Compared to sample I, a similar conversion versus temperature curve can be observed for sample III. Interestingly, the catalysis test in sample III demonstrates that 95% CO conversion can be achieved only when the reaction temperature is elevated to 165°C, apparently higher than the temperature needed for sample I (145°C). And nearly no catalytic properties can be observed in sample IV during the broad temperature range from 40 to 220°C (Fig. 5a). Besides, we can clearly see from the catalytic result of sample V that CO conversion shows a similar curvilinear trend with sample I as temperature increases (Fig. 5a). Catalytic activity typically diminishes when the feature size of catalysts is above the critical one [54]. Former research has revealed that when the ligament size gets larger, the density of active sites, steps and kinks will decrease [55]. As these surface defects can exert an important influence on the adsorption and activation of reactants, ligament coarsening will lead to, more or less, inferior catalytic performances [56]. Therefore, the ligament size seems to be a key factor in determining the catalytic behaviors of the present np-Ag catalysts, on the basis of excluding the possible influence of residual Mg content on the catalytic activity [16]. We also investigated the activation energy of CO oxidation over sample II and III. The relationship between reaction constant and temperature can be described by the Arrhenius equation: (4) ln k = ln A − E a R T where k is the reaction rate constant, A is the Arrhenius factor, E a is the activation energy, R is the molar gas constant (8.314Jmol−1 K−1) and T is the absolute temperature. The following equation is used to determine reaction orders and rate constant at different temperatures: (5) R CO = k [ CO ] a [ O 2 ] b where a and b are corresponding reaction orders, and [CO] as well as [O2] represents volume concentration of CO and O2, respectively. To avoid unnecessary systematic error, the temperature points of 373, 383 and 393K were selected, where the CO conversion was below 70% [57]. Different CO or O2 concentrations (vol%, for [CO] ranging from 0.4% to 1% and [O2] from 10% to 22%) in a total flow rate 40mLmin−1 were considered for the calculation of reaction orders. The as-obtained plot of lnR CO versus ln[CO] or ln[O2] can be seen in Fig. 5b and c, from which the reaction orders a and b were determined (0.43 and 0.16 for sample II; 0.40 and 0.13 for sample III). The values of k calculated from Fig. 5b and c, at the test temperature points 373, 383 and 393K were used for Arrhenius fitting. Fig. 5d shows that the relationship between lnk and 1/T gives a good linear correlation. The calculated activation energies of CO oxidation over sample II and III are 41.1 and 45.8kJmol−1, respectively. The activation energy for sample II was expected to be apparently smaller than that of sample III, due to the fact that sample II owns finer feature size. Nevertheless, it should be noted that even though sample II has slightly smaller activation energy than sample III, the minor difference is not enough to prove their activity distinction. The apparent activity difference mainly exhibits at near complete temperature (for example, T 90%) but these temperature points correspond to higher conversion than 70% which is not suitable for activation energy calculation. Hence we think that, under the ppm-level concentration detection sensitivity for our gas phase composition analyzer, the comparison of near complete conversion temperature is more objective to evaluate the catalytic performance of our catalysts in similar reaction conditions. 3.3 Catalytic activity comparison of np-Ag with supported Ag catalysts Although significant catalytic activity of supported nanoparticulate Ag can be normally observed at feature sizes around or below 10nm, the present unsupported np-Ag catalysts with ligament sizes of about 15–25nm still show a good catalytic performance towards CO oxidation. Similar reports are also available by the work of Fujita et al. [55], in which the unsupported np-Au catalyst can maintain significant catalytic activity even when the ligament size is larger than 30nm. Admittedly, excellent catalytic behaviors have been provided in refs. [16], [17] and [19], in which the temperatures of complete CO conversion for supported Ag catalysts have been reported at near room temperature. This can be attributed to the synergetic effect between Ag and the support as well as the extra heat-treatment in O2 ambience at high temperatures. Exposure to O2 at high temperatures improves the activity of supported Ag catalysts due to the formation of subsurface oxygen [16–19], and following treatment in H2 can further enhance catalytic properties because of the surface faceting of supported Ag catalysts [16,19]. Even so, our unsupported np-Ag catalysts without heat-treatment still show comparable catalytic behaviors with those supported Ag catalysts. In order to evaluate the catalytic performance, T 95% is used as a standard to compare our np-Ag catalysts with other supported Ag under similar reaction conditions. The value of 145°C (T 95%) of sample I in this work is comparable with or better than the supported Ag catalysts. For example, 230°C (T 95%) of Ag/SBA-15 has been reported in ref. [14], while 142°C for Ag/TiO2, 150°C for Ag/TiO2-(NH4)2HPO4, 120°C for Ag/TiO2-P2O5 and 170°C for Ag@APTS-MCM have been given in refs. [15], [58] and [59]. Besides, we also estimated the specific rate of our np-Ag catalysts, and the value at 10% conversion is around 0.024 mol CO g Ag − 1 h − 1 for sample I. This result seems attractive since the reported specific rate at 10% conversion for Ag catalysts supported on SiO2 is 0.01 mol CO g Ag − 1 h − 1 in ref. [60]. Some np-Ag samples were selected for catalytic stability tests, and Fig. 6 a shows the curve of CO conversion versus holding time for sample V. The results demonstrate that the np-Ag catalyst (sample V) can maintain ∼100% conversion at a high temperature of 195°C during the whole time range (300min). It should be noted that the test duration is comparable with the stability measurement for Ag/Ti2O catalyst under similar testing conditions [14]. In addition, during the extended duration of up to 1440min, the conversion can still be maintained at 100% and no catalytic activity loss was observed. Fig. 6b shows the microstructure of sample V after catalysis/stability test (300min). It can be seen that obvious coarsening occurs during the stability test and the ligament size of sample V increases from 19.7±4.4 to 52.4±27.5nm. Moreover, local sintering of adjacent ligaments is inevitable due to the intraparticle diffusion at such high temperature, and some sintering regions are highlighted by dotted circles in Fig. 6b. 3.4 Catalytic mechanism of np-Ag Chemical surface of catalysts can exert a crucial impact on the catalytic activity. Therefore, XPS analysis was carried out to probe the surface elemental information of the np-Ag catalysts. Fig. 7 shows the Ag 3d XPS spectra of the np-Ag catalyst (sample II) before and after catalysis test. The peaks detected at 368.4 and 374.4eV can be attributed to Ag 3d5/2 and Ag 3d3/2 of the metallic Ag, and the 6eV splitting of the 3d doublet also confirms the metallic nature of our np-Ag catalysts [61,62]. However, in order to more rigorously characterize the valence of Ag, we investigated the UV-vis DR spectra of np-Ag (sample II, Fig. 8 ). The patterns in Fig. 8 show the existence of Ag (I) which is concluded from the absorbance peaks in the ultraviolet or near ultraviolet region (from 260 to 350nm) [63]. In contrast, the apparent surface plasma resonance (SPR) band in the range of 400 to 600nm is attributed to Ag (0) [63]. Although the valence of Ag and Au catalysts has been reported to undergo noticeable change after catalysis test [64,65], UV-vis DR spectra, combined with the XPS results and XRD data, exhibit the consistent chemical state of Ag before and after catalysis. Nevertheless, it should be noticeable that the valence change of Ag may take place during the catalytic reaction, and in-situ spectroscopy technique is necessary to further clarify this point. Fig. 9 shows schematic illustration of the whole process including the preparation of our np-Ag catalysts and the involved reaction mechanism. As shown in Fig. 9a, when putting the Mg–Ag alloy in x acid (x acid=tartaric, citric or hydrochloric acid), dealloying begins with the selective dissolution of Mg atoms into the solution in the form of Mg2+ and the surface diffusion of Ag adatoms along the alloy/solution interface (Fig. 9b), leading to the formation of the unique self-similar interpenetrating ligament-channel structure (Fig. 9c). Fig. 9d displays an overview of the whole catalytic process, and the detailed adsorption/reaction information can be found in Fig. 9e–g. Nanoporous metals have been proved to own a high density of steps and kinks which exert an important influence on the surface chemistry and the activation of oxygen species [55]. As shown in Fig. 9e, when exposed to the reaction ambience, adsorption process starts favorably in the surface defect zones where more uncoordinated surface Ag atoms exist. Various oxygen species have been revealed to adsorb well on the surface of Ag atoms [17,19], whereas theoretical study shows that the interaction between Ag clusters and CO is weaker than Cu and Au due to the larger atomic radius of Ag [66]. However, Bloch et al. [67] have found the strong interaction of CO with Ag nanoparticles since the uptake amount of CO is double with the presence of Ag loaded on SiO2, comparing with pure SiO2. The relatively high surface areas of the present np-Ag catalysts supply enough active Ag sites for reactant mixture. As adsorption proceeds, the distance between co-adsorbed O2 and CO decreases. O2 approaches to CO and a metastable O2···CO intermediate emerges [18]. When thermal energy is provided, stretching the bonds between O atoms in O2 can be facilitated (Fig. 9f, indicated by a purple circle). Finally, CO2 is formed and desorbs from the surface (Fig. 9g). The interpenetrating channels provide the effective diffusion routes for desorbed CO2 (indicated with purple arrows in Fig. 9d) and the incoming gas reactants because the size of channels is large enough to allow mass transfer of gas molecules. Thereafter, the unoccupied surface active sites can receive new reactant molecules and catalytic cycles can further continue. Some reports have emphasized the direct reaction between subsurface oxygen and CO after heat-treatment in O2 at high temperatures according to Eley-Rideal mechanism [17,19]. However, the calculated energy barrier shows that the penetration of oxygen into the subsurface or diffusion into the surface is energetically unfavorable, comparing with the formation of surface adsorbed oxygen on Ag atoms [18,68]. Moreover, the calculated reaction barrier of CO with subsurface oxygen through the Ag (111) surface is around 0.91eV, apparently higher than that (0.16eV) of the reaction between CO and surface oxygen [18]. Therefore, Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism [68] discussed hereinbefore seems to be dominant for the catalytic process of the present unsupported np-Ag catalysts. Overall, this unique 3-D bicontinuous interpenetrating ligament-channel structure endows the support-free np-Ag catalysts a good catalytic performance, comparing with many supported Ag catalysts. Further efforts will be exerted on optimizing the compositions of precursors and the dealloying parameters (solutions, temperatures, durations, etc.) to obtain np-Ag catalysts with smaller ligaments and higher structural stability. 4 Conclusions In summary, unsupported nanoporous Ag (np-Ag) catalysts towards CO oxidation can be synthesized via dealloying of rapidly solidified Mg77Ag23 alloy under controllable etching conditions. It has been found that the difference in residual Mg content (8.3 and 2.2at.% for sample I and II, respectively) has no observable influence on the activity of the np-Ag catalysts since the two samples with comparable feature sizes exhibit nearly same catalytic behaviors towards CO oxidation. In addition, the catalytic activity of the np-Ag catalysts owns a nature of size-dependence, and a 95% CO conversion can be achieved at 145°C by the np-Ag catalysts with ligament sizes ranging from around 15–25nm. This catalytic activity of the present np-Ag catalysts is comparable with or better than that of supported Ag catalysts with heat-treatment. The np-Ag catalysts can maintain ∼100% conversion at a high temperature of 195°C during the whole time range (1440min), in spite of inevitable local sintering of ligaments during catalysis run. Besides, Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism seems to be dominant for the catalytic oxidation of CO over the unsupported np-Ag catalysts. It should be noted that CO oxidation is just one example for the present unsupported np-Ag catalysts, which may be effective in other reactions, such as NO reduction, methanol oxidation, etc. Moreover, the following work should be focused upon minimizing the ligament sizes through optimizing the dealloying parameters including solution types, temperatures and durations. And more attention should be paid to improving structural stability (anti-coarsening and anti-sintering) of the unsupported np-Ag catalysts. coredata.dc:description: This work discussed the catalytic performance towards CO oxidation over unsupported nanoporous Ag (np-Ag) catalysts synthesized by dealloying of Mg77Ag23 (at.%) alloy under controllable etching conditions. The np-Ag catalysts were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM), energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) analysis, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (UV-vis DRS). The np-Ag catalysts exhibit an open, bicontinuous interpenetrating ligament-channel structure. The np-Ag samples fabricated under different conditions possess distinct feature sizes ranging from ∼15.7 to ∼142.6nm. Without any heat-treatment, the as-obtained np-Ag catalysts were utilized for catalysis tests. The results reveal that the catalytic activity of the unsupported np-Ag catalysts is comparable with or even better than that of supported Ag catalysts with heat-treatment. In addition, the role of residual Mg and feature size in the catalytic activity of the np-Ag catalysts has been clarified. The catalytic mechanism of the present unsupported np-Ag catalysts has also been discussed.
coredata.dc:title: Unsupported nanoporous Ag catalysts towards CO oxidation
